bibl.title: Letter from Samuel T. Darling to Frederick F. Russell, March 30, 1923

div1.p: Darling discusses the pathological reports of a possible yellow fever case in Lagos, Nigeria.

div1.head: Letter from Samuel T. Darling to Frederick F. Russell, March 30, 1923
div1.opener:
COPY
I. H. B.
Africa
Leesburg, Lee County,
Georgia.
March 30, 1923.
Dear Dr. Russell:
div1.p:
I am very glad to have had a chance to examine
the tissue from the suspected case of yellow fever from
Nigeria (Bradenelli) for the picture is just what I have
for years been expecting to see in some, if not most, of
the suspected cases from West Africa, that is to say, none
of the characteristic changes of yellow fever, but the
pigmentation and bile staining of malaria. I note that the
spleen weighted 18 1/2 oz.; there was no daily examination of
the peripheral blood for plasmodia, and no report on the
examination of tissue smears at autopsy.

Quinine seems to have been discontinued on the
seventh day before death. There was no blood culture.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, (Signed) SAMUEL T. DARLING. Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York City.
